fields.description:
This could be because I still haven't had a successful build - but the failed builds still have a duration and more than zero tests.

Strangely, the Summary page for the build plan does display the build duration and the number of test failures.  But the charts on the reports page do not show any data.
fields.summary: Report graphs are not displaying data: build duration and # of tests

fields.description: When validation of repository fails, the error message is non-descript enough and do not provide sufficient detail to get it correct. http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=15389&tstart=0
fields.summary: Better error reporting when validation of repository fails, including the command used.

fields.description: We need to pass in other java opts (e.g. javax keystore) to Bamboo.
fields.summary: Cannot pass java opts to standalone version

fields.description: I've noticed that repository changes are not associated with a user unless a repository alias is added. This is true even if the user ID and the repository alias are the same.
fields.summary: Bamboo User ID should also be a repository alias

fields.description:
We're having a few performance problems on a project (database and Lucene indexing).  We're extracting stats from the tests. It would be great if Bamboo had hooks that we could add custom data that can be graphed by Bamboo so we could see how this data changes across builds.

That would be very cool!
fields.summary: We able to add custom project specific Build Telemetry data

fields.description:
When you create a plan, bamboo does a p4 sync -f  of the client paths specfied when the plan is created.  I believe this should be an option.  

When you create a perforce client, it usually asks you if you want to sync, so you may not need to do a full sync again when creating the plan - that would be wasteful.

If you could just give the creator of the plan a checkbox that says "Force sync when plan is created", then if a user did not check that option, bamboo would just do a p4 sync without the "-f" option.
fields.summary: You should have an option not to forcibly sync the first time a plan is created using perforce

fields.description: I've installed on my windows box, by way of trying out this (very interesting) CI solution. Unfortunately I don't seem to be able to use it against our CVSNT installation as we restrict the protocols to SSPI or CVSNT-SSERVER for security reasons. When I try to add a new project the CVSROOT field on the second step is rejected as invalid due to the unsupported protocol.
fields.summary: Support for sspi and/or cvnnt-sserver protocols in CVVSNT integration

fields.description: For a given build plan, the clover test coverage graph does not show any values on the y-axis, making it hard to see what's going on.
fields.summary: Clover test coverage graph doesn't have the values in y-axis

fields.description: Only bash and script builders available on the choose a builder screen, no JDK options.  Using the .war distribution
fields.summary: ant/maven builders not available

fields.description:
I cannot get the Bamboo-JIRA integration to work. I have correctly configured the JIRA URL (i.e. the JIRA links on various Bamboo pages correctly link to JIRA and I have tested the issued URL using Firefox and it is correct). However the SOAP-RPC integration fails. It appears that Bamboo is attempting to log into JIRA, but using the wrong SOAP-RPC method.

Using tcpdump, the web service conversation is:

Bamboo -> JIRA
POST /jira/rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2 HTTP/1.0
Content-Type: text/xml; charset=utf-8
Accept: application/soap+xml, application/dime, multipart/related, text/*
User-Agent: Axis/1.4
Host: hornblend.sg01.savi.com
Cache-Control: no-cache
Pragma: no-cache
SOAPAction: ""
Content-Length: 480

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><soapenv:Body><ns1:login soapenv:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" xmlns:ns1="http://soap.rpc.jira.atlassian.com"><in0 xsi:type="xsd:string">engbuild</in0><in1 xsi:type="xsd:string">XXXXXX</in1></ns1:login></soapenv:Body></soapenv:Envelope>

JIRA -> Bamboo
HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error
Date: Thu, 25 Jan 2007 01:09:20 GMT
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
Content-Type: text/xml;charset=utf-8
Connection: close

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"><soapenv:Body><soapenv:Fault><faultcode xmlns:ns1="http://xml.apache.org/axis/">ns1:Client</faultcode><faultstring>No such operation 'login'</faultstring><detail><ns2:hostname xmlns:ns2="http://xml.apache.org/axis/">hornblend.sg01.savi.com</ns2:hostname></detail></soapenv:Fault></soapenv:Body></soapenv:Envelope>
fields.summary: JIRA integration fails on JIRA 3.6 with "no such method"

fields.description:
Currently errors on the dashboard only show the plan that caused them, not the exact build.

Knowing which build caused an error is vital for tracking down its cause.
fields.summary: Errors on dashboard should show which build they were raised in

fields.description: When viewing a plan configuration, the build strategy shows 'triggered build', but the IP address isn't shown. You need to click edit to see the IP address at all.
fields.summary: Display build trigger IP address on 'view plan configuration' page

fields.description:
To replicate:

Go to a project source repository config page
Select "Trigger"
Enter "svn.atlassian.com" for the originating IP

Result:
Error message

FQDNs should be looked-up.
fields.summary: Trigger originating IP field doesn't accept FQDNs

fields.description:
I want to send a link to someone for the 'Source Repository' tab in the plan configuration screen. At the moment, if I send a link, it just opens on the first tab.

Perhaps you can use anchors to update the URL and provide the correct tab when the page loads. For example:

http://panda:8080/bamboo/build/admin/buildConfiguration!default.action?buildKey=CONFFUNC-MAIN#source

(Underlying issue: all content in your web app should be linkable.)
fields.summary: Permalinks for tabs in plan configuration screen

fields.description:
The following JARs need to be included for Crowd to work:

commons-codec-1.3.jar
commons-collections-3.1.jar
commons-httpclient-3.0.jar
commons-logging-1.0.4.jar
jaxen-1.1-beta-9.jar
jdom-1.0.jar
oscache-2.3.jar
spring-1.2.8.jar
stax-api-1.0.1.jar
wsdl4j-1.5.2.jar
wstx-asl-2.9.3.jar
xfire-all-1.2.1.jar

The most important one here is the {{commons-httpclient-3.0.jar}} must be version 3.0 or higher because of a library change after rc3 otherwise the existing version of the libs can be used EXCEPT for the httpclient.

Attached are the new sample configuration files.
fields.summary: Add XFire (Crowd) dependacy libraries and adjust configuration file to have stubbed out Crowd configurations.

fields.description:
Jetty standalone version starts up without the jetty configuration file.

We need this to enable this for SMTP via JNDI. Created as a result of investigation from BSP-3.
fields.summary: Standalone Jetty starts without configuration file

fields.description:
Right now, the only way to use Perforce is to specify your perforce password in an environment variable.

Bamboo should allow you to set your password like CVS or SVN.

Issue raised from forum: http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257240925#257240925.
fields.summary: Perforce Configuration should allow passwords

fields.description:

fields.description:
I created a second build plan for a project using the same perforce client spec.  I think when the initial build is performed for a plan, Bamboo deletes the source directory and then does a sync.  Since perforce already thought the directory was up to date, nothing was synced.

I guess the thinking is that you should create different perforce specs for each plan - and that makes sense, as you wouldn't want the delta build kicking off at the same time that a manual build was running using the same directory.

I think Bamboo should not let you create two builds using the same perforce client spec if this is the intention - or it should not do a clean of the directory when you create a new plan using the same perforce client spec.
fields.summary: Creating a plan with the same perforce client spec - directory is deleted and not resynced

fields.description:
As discussed in the [forums|http://forum.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257240764&#257240764] (copied below for completeness); allow for option to have parent builds block children.  This would allow children projects to use the most recent libraries from the parent, and prevent false positive builds where the parent is broken, or breaks compatibility.  A side affect is that this also makes the build sequence more efficient by not building children that would obviously fail (when parent is failing).
----
Original response in forum:

Basil,

So what you want is the ability to "block" dependent builds when a parent build is running? e.g.

Build A has child builds B, C and D is a child of C.

If I check into all the sources simultaneously (though obviously A has to build first), then you'd want A to build, and B & C not to build until A is finished? And D not until C is finished? Are you doing this so since the child builds uses the libraries in the their builds?
> Basil: Yes, that is correct.

Also, if A build fails, B and C would not build. Would that be okay?
> Basil: Yes that is what's expected.
fields.summary: "Block" dependent builds when a parent build is running

fields.description:
I have a multi-project build using maven 2. Not all projects in this multi-project build have unit tests. 
The build plan is configured to look for test results in **/target/surefire-reports/*.xml
From the log i can see that the maven 2 build is executed successfully by bamboo.

Bamboo is failing the build due to not found tests:
{code}No failed tests found, a possible compilation error.{code}
{code}Could not find ant Junit test results in the /home/​app28/​data/​xml-data/​build-dir/​PCQ-TRUNK directory.{code}

This build is doing fine, so why is bamboo failing the build?
fields.summary: A succesfull building maven 2 multi-project build is failing due to missing test results

fields.description:
If you look at this url:

http://81.17.46.170/bamboo/build/viewBuildResults.action?buildKey=WICKET2X-WICKET&buildNumber=10

you see a build of our open source Wicket Project.

It is telling me that 85 test are failing, but if you look closely you see that in the TestCase column it only reports
the same one over and over again ( Render home page_3) 
One for every "TestSuite" but that TestSuite is not a suite, it is a TestCase by itself.

if you click on one that he says it fails:
http://81.17.46.170/bamboo/browse/WICKET2X-WICKET-10/test/wicket.AttributeModifierComponentTest:testRenderHomePage_3
then you see this:
Test Class: wicket.AttributeModifierComponentTest
Method:testRenderHomePage_3 

but AttributeModifierComponentTest doesn't have a testRenderHomePage_3
you can see in the stacktrace: 
wicket/markup/html/basic/SimplePageExpectedResult_3.html expected:<... ...> but was:<......>
junit.framework.ComparisonFailure: wicket/markup/html/basic/SimplePageExpectedResult_3.html expected:&...
...& but was:&......&
	at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:81)
	at wicket.util.diff.DiffUtil.validatePage(DiffUtil.java:107)
	at wicket.WicketTestCase.executeTest(WicketTestCase.java:81)
	at wicket.markup.html.basic.SimplePageTest.testRenderHomePage_3(SimplePageTest.java:283)

Where it really comes from And that s stacktrace is mentioned everywhere.

So it seems to report many times the same error on in what he things is a TestSuite.

the other strange thing is that when you scrolldown to the fixed cases. You see as far as i see
the exact same list (of testsuites). But then it tell is that it is fixed!
and if you click on one. You see that it gives the error description. So it is not really fixed...

fields.description:
As a 'manager' of a development project, I have gotten to the stage where I want to switch off my immediate email notifications for build failures (as there are too many), but I still want to keep on top of how the projects are progressing.  Information like (for each project):

- How many builds today?  
- How many committers?
- How many builds passed / failed?
- Average time to fix a failure?  How many hours today was the build failing?

Of course with click-throughs to all the appropriate places.

I know that I can get this information online, but an emailed notification would also be useful.

Scott
fields.summary: Daily 'summary' email for projects/plans you are interested in

fields.summary: Added two builds to the queue, canceled the 2nd one, got a hibernate exception

fields.description: We would like to know who started a build.  Could this be logged and displayed in the build info?
fields.summary: Log the user who started the build

fields.description: When downloading the standalone zip file the {{start-bamboo.sh}} script is missing and the server cannot be run on non-windows computers.  The correct script is included in the .tar.gz though.
fields.summary: Start script missing from standalone zip file

fields.description: It would be nice to show an ETA on the queued builds as well. That way, we can roughly look at how long all the builds will take?
fields.summary: Show ETA of queued builds

fields.description: People have been asking for examples of JIRA integration. We should see if the opensource instance can be used to showcase some of the integration features or not.
fields.summary: Setup test projects with JIRA integration

fields.description:
A [NAnt|http://nant.sourceforge.net/] builder that produces [NUnit|http://www.nunit.org/] test reports.

Adding a NAnt builder itself should be pretty trivial, but we'll have sure we find test projects to test out the NUnit test reports. We need to check if the NUnit tests produce the same XML format or not.
fields.summary: Native support for NAnt builder

fields.description:
This is not a major thing, but it quite annoys me.

The build progress in the Dashboard seems to be using an average of past build times including failures as well.
This is not very accurate since if we have many build failures, the average time will go down quite significantly.
Maybe it should be using an average build time of past build successes instead?

Thanks,
Herry
fields.summary: Build progress is not accurate enough

fields.description:
When builds configured to use test reporting or Clover fail, they generate a zero datapoint.  In an ideal world, builds don't break, but when they do they create unnecessary discontinuities that obscure the graph trends.

May I suggest that, if possible, no data be generated for those builds?
fields.summary: Failed builds should not generate some data points

fields.description: If you have a password with @ in it, the CVS Connection will fail
fields.summary: CVS connection fails if password has @ in it

fields.description: See the attached screenshot.  Core 3 queue is usually on the left.
fields.summary: Display of the build queues is stuffed

fields.description:
It would be great if we have an option to attach the build.log in the mail notification for build failures.
Most people will just like to see at the mail and figure out what's wrong rather than have to log in to Bamboo all the time 
and doing lots of clicks before finding out what is wrong.

Your support is greatly appreciated. Thanks!
fields.summary: Build email doesn't contain enough information in the case of build failure

fields.description:
Some BuildStrategy like {{Manual}} simply catches RepostoryExceptions, logs it and keeps going. It means that if the CVS repo is down, then the user never really know about it. This is obviously not good, we need to at least log it to the UI and cancel the build. 

Currently logs something like

fields.summary: Manual build strategy gobbles up CVS errors

fields.description:
Some people have CVS_RSH property set to work with sshagent so that they don't need to enter passwords for SSH connections.

This is currently ignored by Bamboo and a password is required to be entered. 

We should investigate to see if we can make this work by added CVS_RSH property to the environment of the CVS Client.

I *suspect* this should be possible. See

http://www.netbeans.org/kb/articles/sourceforge.html
http://www.netbeans.org/kb/articles/cvs-ssh.html
fields.summary: CVS Client should use the CVS_RSH environment variable if available

fields.description:
At the moment, if you supply a wrong password or no password when using a CVS repository with the :ext protocol, 

e.g.
{noformat}
CVS ROOT: :ext:mchai@cvs.atlassian.com:/cvsroot/atlassian
Password: booyah
{noformat}

just says that "Cannot open connection". We should detect that message and that the CVSROOT is an :ext and could also mean that the password is invalid.
fields.summary: Improve validation for CVS :ext

fields.description: On the configure mail page, if you enter details of your mail server (and not the JNDI settings), you still see the JNDI label on the view screen
fields.summary: Rougue JNDI mail settings label

fields.description: It would be great if it was possible to add a 'special' type of comment for a build if it's broken, which would be displayed on the dashboard until the build is fixed.  That way, developers would know straight away why a build is failing on the dashboard, even if in the meantime other builds ran that also failed.  (Currently the little comment icon is only displayed for the build against which the comment was made...if the build runs again and fails again, you do not see that comment icon anymore).  In other words a 'Why was the build broken message' that doesn't go away until the build is fixed.
fields.summary: Manual build broken message displayed on the Dashboard until a build is fixed.

fields.description:
Queues can pick what build plans they are applicable to. However, when you delete a plan, this doesn't get removed.

We need to add this the relationship through Hibernate so that any deletes can be easily cascaded.
fields.summary: Deleting builds doesn't seem to remove it from Queues

fields.description: It appears that we have re-broken this in the UI redesign.
fields.summary: Commit comments lose line breaks

fields.description: When I go to add a Builder of type "Ant" and fill in anything for "Label" and "Path" and click on "Save" the line gets cleared back to "Custom Command" and no builder gets created.
fields.summary: Can't add builder of type Ant

fields.description: As it stands we can have 'All Plans' and 'My Plans'. It would be neat to allow multiple 'All Plans'-type tabs to help organize builds. We might eventually have 100 builds or more and it would be easier to find it if we could break up the 'All Plans' list and not have to wade through the whole thing.
fields.summary: Allow multiple tabs on dashboard page

fields.description: Anywhere that references a change should (please?) have a web link to the Perforce changlist, or file, that changed (like in Jira!) Knowing *what* changed is a good start, but it would be convenient to be able to click on it and see the dffs, history, etc.
fields.summary: Add web link to perforce changelist

fields.description:
Have a 'picker' interface for adding projects to build queues (two windows, arrows to shuffle selections between them.)

We only have about 10 builds right now, but if I want to manage a build queue I ofter forget to hold down the Control key before I select or un-select an item in a queue's list, thusly wiping out my previous selections.
fields.summary: Checkboxes for build queues

fields.description: Typing in a bunch of e-mail addresses for notifications is a chore. It would be nice to have a 'picker' for this, which uses the userlist to populate the notification list. Or better yet, allow users to subscribe to builds by clicking a link (like in Jira.)
fields.summary: Picker for e-mail notifications

fields.description: It would be nice to allow arbitrary post-build commands (commandline, let's say) to be attached directly to a build. As it stands now I have to make a separate build/plan that just runs a simple script (say, to deploy a windows .msi to a remote machine), which effectively doubles the number of builds that appear in my master list. It would be cool if the 'script' build type can sort of be attached to a build as well and not show up in the main list.
fields.summary: Allow arbitrary post-build commands

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to monitor multiple depots/paths in Perforce for changes to trigger a build. VisualStudio projects (especially web) normally have many sub-projects that might reside under different root depots.
fields.summary: Allow multiple depots in Perforce connection

fields.description: NTLM/Domain authentication would be nice to have with Bamboo, to sort of auto-generate the userlist.
fields.summary: NTLM authentication

fields.description:

fields.description:
Recently we seem to be having issues relating to builds, whereby it does a checkout, runs a second detection, then places the build in the build queue:

{queue}
Detected that build "CAT - CPA" needs building.
Placing build "CAT - CPA" on the build queue.
{queue}

Which all looks good until you realise it's stuck at building for 1 second for over 3 hours:

{quote}
org.springframework.transaction.CannotCreateTransactionException: Could not open Hibernate Session for transaction; nested exception is net.sf.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: Cannot open connection
net.sf.hibernate.exception.GenericJDBCException: Cannot open connection

	at $Proxy7.getAllBuilds(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.doTask(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:106)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.run(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:77)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534)
Caused by: java.sql.SQLException: Connections could not be acquired from the underlying database!
	at com.mchange.v2.sql.SqlUtils.toSQLException(SqlUtils.java:104)

fields.description: Currently Bamboo feels very sluggish over a slow network since it download all the JS files with every hit. We need to implement a version of the URL rewrite filter to see if we can fix this.
fields.summary: Set caching headers for static files

fields.description:
On Build Configuration page, if you click "edit" button it allows you to change settings on all available tabs - Plan Details, Source Repository, Builder Configuration, etc. You can switch to any tab and make changes. If you switch back to can see the the changes are still preserved. However, if you click save button, only changes in the current tab will be saved. Changes in other tabs are lost.

For example, if I change Builder JDK in Builder Configuration tab to some other value then switch to Source Repository tab and click save, the change I made is reverted back to the original.

I am not sure is this the expected behavior or a bug. But in my case, it is quite confusing.
fields.summary: Configuration changes are lost if save in an other tab

fields.description:
I received this email this morning, and it struck me that it could be improved:

{noformat}
The project Confluence - Unit Tests has the following 1 change(s) by 1 author(s):

*Samuel Le Berrigaud* made the following changes at 2007-01-09 09:45:20.0

Comment:
Fixing unit tests after refactoring cache managers.

> > confluence/src/test/etc/testApplicationContext.xml (1.136)
> > confluence/src/test/java/com/atlassian/confluence/cluster/TestEvictedCache.java (1.4)
> > confluence/src/test/java/com/atlassian/confluence/core/TestDefaultContentPropertyManager.java (1.9)



The build has 0 failed tests and 1066 successful tests.

Click http://keg.sydney.atlassian.com:8080/bamboo/browse/CONF-MAIN-1305 to find out more.

Thanks,

Bamboo
{noformat}

Some suggestions:
* We know how many authors and comments there are.  Why the '(s)' ?
* Can we use a more user friendly date?  How about, 9:45am on 9/Jan/07 ?
* If all tests are successful, can we just say 'All 1066 tests passed' ?  '0 failed tests' whilst technically correct, sounds awful.
* The 'from' address is just 'bamboo@atlassian.com'.  Can we change that to have a nice name (perhaps use the application's name?  'Atlassian's Bamboo instance' or something similar?

It would also be great to have HTML versions of these emails, but I'll raise a separate issue for that.
fields.summary: Improve email notifications

fields.description: Currently there are multiple queues, and once on a queue a build remains there until executed, even if there are empty queue available.  It would be better to have a single 'hopper' queue which feeds to multiple workers.
fields.summary: Having independant build queues underutilises resources

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo can be viewable by non-logged in users. Also, users can sign up themselves.

For public instances, we should disallow this to happen. For 1.0, functionality as below:

- Administration should have option to control "sign up" functionality - on or off. If off, the sign up page is disabled and links disappear.
- Administration should have option to control "viewable publicly" function - yes or no. If no, anonymous users cannot view anything in Bamboo until they have signed in.
fields.summary: Security and Login Improvements

fields.description:
On this page:

  http://opensource.bamboo.atlassian.com/build/admin/buildConfiguration.action?buildKey=SITEMESH-TOMCAT5517

You can see that the configuration tabs are of different sizes.  I presume that you want to 'nowrap' them (or whatever the css equivalent is).
fields.summary: Edit configuration needs formatting fixes

fields.description: When you create a new project, the drop-down to choose the project seems to be ordered in creation date.  We should make this case insensitive alpha ordering.
fields.summary: Project names not ordered in dropdown to create project

fields.description:
Text on the top of the screen:

  http://opensource.bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/SITEMESH-UNIT

"No previous builds of Sitemesh - Unit Tests exists" (probably can't see it now that the project has built.

You can have "no previous builds of X exist", or "no previous build of X exists", but you can't have a double plural.

Also considering 'quoting' or 'italicising' the project name.  As in the case above, it was hard to tell which part of the sentence was the project & build name.
fields.summary: Typo and user interface improvement

fields.description: On step 5 of setting up a project, if the 'javascript' checkbox isn't shown, then you can't create a project, as the save button isn't shown.  See screenshots.
fields.summary: No way to 'complete' setting up a project as 'save' hidden by javascript

fields.description:
Now this could be an issue in our CVS servers, but I'm not aware of any problems.

Creating a new plan, to check out from CVS using the URL:

CVS Root:      :pserver:anonymous@cvs.jaxen.codehaus.org:/cvs/jaxen/
Module: jaxen

Cannot connect to CVS root: Authentication failed. Response from server was: "error 0 /cv".

Now if I do this at the command line I get:

$ cvs -d :pserver:anonymous@cvs.jaxen.codehaus.org:/cvs/jaxen/ co jaxen
cvs checkout: Updating jaxen
U jaxen/.cvsignore
U jaxen/INSTALL
...

all good

I've tried this in two different Bamboo instances - same error.

There's nothing relevant in the log (i.e. nothing related to the error occurring - just some activity on another plan that's building)

A problem in Bamboo? or a problem in the Codehaus CVS servers?
fields.summary: Problems checking out from Codehaus CVS
